Base.Explanation: Edit an existing user account. The account can be an Active Directory user account, a local computer user account, Windows NT4 domain or workgroup account. The account can be identified by a variable containing the 'User Object' (Active Directory only) or the SAM account name together with the name of a domain or domain controller.

ArrayElement.Name: User Object
ArrayElement.Description: A data structure representing the user account. This property can only be used for Active Directory user accounts. For other user accounts, use the properties 'Username' and 'Domain' or 'Domain controller' to specify the user account. For this property, use the action 'Get user (AD)' to find the user account in Active Directory and setup the variable that contains the 'User Object'.

ArrayElement.Name: Username
ArrayElement.Description: The user name (SAM account name) of the user account. For Active Directory user accounts, you can also specify the user account with property 'User Object'. If you use this property, you must also specify property 'Domain' or 'Domain controller'.

ArrayElement.Name: Domain
ArrayElement.Description: The DNS or NETBIOS domain name of the user account. For Active Directory user accounts, you can also specify the user account with property 'User Object'. If you use this property, you must also specify property 'Username'. For local computer user accounts or workgroup accounts, you cannot use this property. For these accounts, use property 'Domain controller' instead.

ArrayElement.Name: Domain controller
ArrayElement.Description: The DNS or NETBIOS domain name of the computer that maintains the user account. For Active Directory user accounts, you can also specify the user account with property 'User Object'. If you use this property, you must also specify property 'Username'.

ArrayElement.Name: Password generator
ArrayElement.Description: A password can be generated automatically. The 'Password generator' specifies how the password is generated, e.g. password length, password complexity requirements, password output variable etc. When this property is specified the password is generated automatically. The generated password is stored in the specified output variable (default: %Password%).

ArrayElement.Name: Password
ArrayElement.Description: The password of the user account.

ArrayElement.Name: User must change password at next logon
ArrayElement.Description: The password is expired. Use this property to force the user to change the password at the next logon. Note that the user can logon using the current password.

ArrayElement.Name: User cannot change password
ArrayElement.Description: The user cannot change password. When the user cannot change the password, only the administrator can change the password.

ArrayElement.Name: Password never expires
ArrayElement.Description: The password should never expire on the account. Default value: 'No' (password does expire).

ArrayElement.Name: Account disabled
ArrayElement.Description: The user's account is disabled. If a user account is disabled, the account does exist but cannot be used to logon to the network.

ArrayElement.Name: Unlock the account
ArrayElement.Description: A user account is locked when the user tries to logon to the network with an incorrect password for to many times (according to the domain policy). When an account is locked, the user cannot logon, even if the correct password is specified. By unlocking the account, the user can logon again.

Base.Explanation: Create an Exchange 2000 or Exchange 2003 mailbox for a user account. The mailbox is created on the specified Exchange server. The user account should already exist.

ArrayElement.Name: User Object
ArrayElement.Description: A data structure representing the user account. The property is used to identifiy the user account for the mailbox and is normally generated as a variable by a previous script action ('Creating user (AD)').

ArrayElement.Name: Exchange server
ArrayElement.Description: The name of the Exchange server on which the mailbox will be created. The name of the Exchange server is used to determine the 'mailbox store' that is used for the mailbox.

ArrayElement.Name: Mailbox store
ArrayElement.Description: The name of the Exchange mailbox store used for the new mailbox. If there is only one mailbox store on the Exchange server, you do not need to specify the property. By default, an Exchange 2000/2003 server only has a single mailbox store. In more complex environment, multiple mailbox stores can reside on an Exchange server. In this case, you need to select the full LDAP name of the store.

ArrayElement.Name: Domain controller
ArrayElement.Description: Optional: The (NETBIOS) name of the domain controller used to access to the Exchange mailbox store. Depending on the logged on user account and the network domain configuration, it might be necessary to specify this property. For instance, if you are logged on in a trusted Windows NT4 domain and you are creating mailboxes in a Windows 2000/2003 environment, you must specify the NETBIOS name of a domain controller of the Windows 2000/2003 domain for this property.

ArrayElement.Name: Alias
ArrayElement.Description: Optional: The Alias property specifies the alias used for E-mail address generation. By default, E-mail addresses are generated based on the name of the user account.

ArrayElement.Name: E-mail addresses
ArrayElement.Description: Optional: The E-mail addresses specified for the Exchange mailbox. By default, the E-mail addresses are generated automatically when the mailbox is created. By specifying this property you can configure additional E-mail addresses.

ArrayElement.Name: Auto-update E-mail addresses
ArrayElement.Description: The E-mail addresses for the Exchange mailbox can be generated according to the recipient's policy by specifying this option.

ArrayElement.Name: Hide from address book
ArrayElement.Description: The property specifies whether the recipient is displayed in the address book. Default value: 'No'.

Base.Explanation: Create a new Exchange 2007 mailbox for an existing Active Directory user account.

Base.Name: Database name
Base.Description: This parameter specifies which Exchange database will contain the new mailbox for the user. For example: 'Mailbox database', 'SERVERNAME\Mailbox Database' or 'SERVERNAME\Storage Group Name\Mailbox Database'.

Base.Name: Identity
Base.Description: This parameter specifies the user or InetOrgPerson of the new mailbox. Use for example the distinguished name (CN=jsmith,OU=sales,DC=tools4ever,DC=com), the domain\account name (tools4ever.com\Jsmith), the User principal name (UPN). (JSmith@tools4ever.com) or the GUID.

Base.Name: Alias
Base.Description: Optional value. The alias (mail nickname) of the user's new mailbox. The alias can be a combination of characters separated by a period with no intervening spaces. Do not use special characters in the alias. For example: 'JSmith'. If not specified, the alias will be generated automatically.

Base.Name: Domain controller
Base.Description: Optional value. The name of the domain controller used to write this configuration change to Active Directory. Use the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the domain controller. For example: EXCHSERVER.tools4ever.com..

Base.Name: Exchange GUID
Base.Description: Optional value. This parameter returns the Exchange GUID of the new mailbox.

Base.Name: Legacy Exchange DN
Base.Description: Optional value. This parameter returns the Legacy Exchange Distinguished Name of the new mailbox.

Base.Explanation: Setup a session with the Powershell Agent service. The session is requied for a number of UMRA script actions that use the Powershell Agent service. See the online help for more information.

ArrayElement.Name: Session ID
ArrayElement.Description: The identifier of the Powershell Agent service session. The value should be stored in a variable that is used in subsequent UMRA acions thath use the Powershell Agent service session. This property is an 'output only' property. By default, the value for this property is stored in variable %PowershellAgentSessionId%.

Base.Explanation: Setup an Exchange session for PowerShell to manage an Exchange 2010 server.

Base.Name: Session ID
Base.Description: This parameter identifies the PowerShell Agent service session.

Base.Name: Connection URI
Base.Description: The Connection URI parameter specifies the location of the PowerShell. For example: 'https://[ExchangeServer].tools4ever.local/Powershell' or 'https://[ExchangeServer]/Powershell' or 'https://ps.outlook.com/powershell/'.

Base.Name: Credential User Name
Base.Description: Optional. The credential user name, use this parameter when you want to access the Exchange Server with an explicit account. The user name must be of an account inside the domain of the Exchange server and must have access to the Exchange server For example: 'tools4ever\JohnSmith'. If not specified, a default security context is tried for the specified authentication method, Generally this will be the security context of the Powershell Agent Service account.

Base.Name: Credential Password
Base.Description: Optional. The encrypted password of the account you want to use to access the Exchange server with. The input should be the encrypted value of the password.

Base.Name: Skip certificate check
Base.Description: With the 'Skip certificate check' parameter you can choose to connect to the exchange server without checking the certificate of the exchange server.

Base.Name: Skip prerequisites test
Base.Description: With the 'Skip prerequisites test' parameter you can choose to skip the check for PowerShell version, windows remoting version, execution policy. Set this only if you're completely sure the check fails, but the settings are correct.

Base.Name: Authentication
Base.Description: Specifies the mechanism that is used to authenticate the user's credentials. Valid values are "Default", "Basic", "Credssp", "Digest", "Kerberos", "Negotiate", and "NegotiateWithImplicitCredential". The default value is "Default".

Base.Name: Advanced: Logging mask
Base.Description: The mask specified here, determines the logging output of ALL the PowerShell actions in this session. Default all messages except debug messages are shown. The mask is build from the following numbers: 1 = Normal, 2 = Error, 4 = Warning, 8 = Info, 128 = Debug. If not specified the number 7 is used.

Base.Explanation: Create a new Exchange 2010 mailbox for an existing Active Directory user account.

Base.Name: Session ID
Base.Description: This parameter identifies the PowerShell Agent service session.

Base.Name: Domain controller
Base.Description: Optional value. The name of the domain controller used for reading or writing configuration changes. If not specified, Exchange will determine a domain controller. To prevent replication issues always use the same domain controller in the same session. Use the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the domain controller. For example 'EXCHSERVER.tools4ever.com'.

Base.Name: Identity
Base.Description: The user or 'InetOrgPerson' of the new mailbox. Use for example the distinguished name 'CN=jsmith,OU=sales,DC=tools4ever,DC=com', the domain\account name 'tools4ever.com\Jsmith', the user principal name (UPN) 'JSmith@tools4ever.com' or the GUID.

Base.Name: Database name
Base.Description: The Exchange database which will contain the new mailbox for the user. For example 'Mailbox database' or 'SERVERNAME\Mailbox Database'.

Base.Name: Active Sync Mailbox Policy
Base.Description: The mailbox policy to enable for the new mailbox. If not specified, the default mailbox policy is used.

Base.Name: Alias
Base.Description: Optional value. The alias (mail nickname) of the user's new mailbox. The alias can be a combination of characters separated by a period with no intervening spaces. Do not use special characters in the alias. For example 'JSmith'. If not specified, the alias will be generated automatically.

Base.Name: Managed Folder Mailbox Policy
Base.Description: Optional value. The 'Managed Folder Mailbox Policy' parameter specifies the managed folder mailbox policy to enable for the mailbox that you create. If you do not specify this parameter, the default managed folder mailbox policy is used.

Base.Name: Managed Folder Mailbox Policy Allowed
Base.Description: Optional value. The 'Managed Folder Mailbox Policy Allowed' parameter bypasses the warning that messaging records management features are not supported for e-mail clients using versions of Outlook earlier than Outlook 2007. When a managed folder mailbox policy is assigned to a mailbox using the ManagedFolderMailboxPolicy parameter, the warning appears by default unless ManagedFolderMailboxPolicyAllowed is used.

Base.Name: Exchange GUID
Base.Description: Optional value. This parameter returns the Exchange GUID of the new mailbox.

Base.Name: Legacy Exchange DN
Base.Description: Optional value. This parameter returns the Legacy Exchange Distinguished Name of the new mailbox.

Base.Explanation: Closes the Exchange session inside the current Powershell session. Use the action Release Powershell Agent service session to subsequently release the Powershell session itself.

Base.Name: Session ID
Base.Description: This parameter identifies the PowerShell Agent service session.

Base.Explanation: Release a session with the Powershell Agent service. The session should be previously setup with action 'Setup Powershell Agent service session'. The session is identified by property 'Session ID'.

ArrayElement.Name: Session ID
ArrayElement.Description: The identifier of the Powershell Agent service session. The value should correspond with property 'Session ID' of action 'Setup Powershell Agent service session', called previously.

Base.Explanation: Edit an existing user account. The account can be an Active Directory user account, a local computer user account, Windows NT4 domain or workgroup account. The account can be identified by a variable containing the 'User Object' (Active Directory only) or the SAM account name together with the name of a domain or domain controller.
